headline: Potato Latkes
description: These potato latkes are made with shredded potatoes and grated onions bound with flour and eggs, then fried until crispy outside and tender inside.

video.description: Watch how to make these top-rated potato latkes.
video.name: Potato Latkes I

name: Potato Latkes
recipeIngredient: 1 large egg, beaten, or more to taste
0.5 teaspoon salt, or more to taste
0.25 cup peanut oil for frying, or as needed

recipeInstructions.text: Slice peeled potatoes and run through a food processor fitted with the grater attachment. Place shredded potatoes in a cheesecloth and wring, extracting as much moisture as possible.
Measure 2 cups shredded, drained potatoes and place into a medium bowl; save any extra for another use. Add egg, flour, onion, and salt, and stir until well combined.

Heat 1/4 inch of oil in a large, heavy-bottomed skillet over medium-high heat. Place large spoonfuls of potato mixture into the hot oil, pressing down on them to form 1/4- to 1/2-inch-thick patties. Cook until golden brown, 4 to 5 minutes. Flip and repeat on the other side.
Remove to a paper towel-lined plate to drain while you cook any remaining latkes. Serve hot.

review.reviewBody: I was in a hurry for a side so I used frozen tater tots. Thawed them in microwave and crushed them up and followed the recipe. They came out really good! My family liked them and it sure beat shredding the potatoes.

This was too much like a hash brown for my family. We use more flour and it's more of a pancake filled with potato and onion goodness. I use a griddle with a little oil and cook them just like a pancake. My kids have tried them both ways and don't like them the way this recipe makes them. They like them with a bit more of a pancake consistency.

Great recipe! Made exactly the same way as my mother did, with one minor difference. I have made them twice since Hanukkah began on 12/18. This recipe gave me between 8-12 decent size latkes. I plan to make them again before the holiday ends. Highly recommend. Great with either sour cream or apple sauce.
I loved this simple recipe. Easy to make a double batch. I substituted matzah meal for the flour. Served it with applesauce and sour cream and bit of chives. Great first night of Hanukkah
It was delicious and wish I'd made more!! I added garlic powder with the salt and pepper and of course we enjoy3d it with sour cream. The kids loved it !!
I think this recipe was simple and easy and was very delicious! I usually don't cook last minute but for this recipe, any time!
Promised a yield of 10 to 12 latkes but I only ended up with 4
Delicious!
These were delicious! I made no changes.
Tried to make a smaller quantity. Used too much egg and I would add herbs and more onion next time
I made this recipe as written. My husband and I just didn't like them.
Quite good! Followed the recipe exactly and then drained some of the eggy liquid from the mix after Reading so many reviews saying to use fewer eggs. These came out beautifully.
Best recipe ever! Squeeze the liquid out and let the potatoes be almost dry before you proceed. Make super crispy potato latkes
Loved this recipe!! I used the already shredded potatoes found in the refrigerated section of the grocery store (made this recipe so easy !) Will definitely make again.

Made these yummies today!!! Made it just like the recipe but extra onions (2 TBSP), and wow, yum!!! I saw a suggestion said to serve it with sour cream, applesauce and topped with green onions. I never would of thought of topping the sour cream and applesauce together but wow, what a great flavor. Tasted wonderful with the Beef Brisket I prepared too and wow!! Best dinner. I was going to take a photo with the sour cream and applesauce toppings but I ate it before I thought of it. I will be making these more often!! I highly recommend this recipe! Happy Hanukkah!
Yummy!!! I mixed fresh green onions in the batch at the same time instead of a garnish.
I used leftover mashed potatoes instead of the grated ones and it turned out delicious ...
I made these with grated potato and onion, I used about 1/2" oil in the pan to almost deep fry them, they were really really good!
Draining the water from potatoes is key; I reduced the eggs. Doubled the recipe but only used 4 large eggs total. Salt after cooking.
They were good but I think it calls for too much salt. I wish I had used half.
Delicious. Used green onions in mixture. Also put applesauce and sour cream as topping and garnished with more finely chopped green onion. Will definitely use often.
Everyone loved them for Chanukah. Was simple and easy to make. Will definitely use this recipe again.
good recipe but cut the salt in half and reduce the eggs to 2/3

I did change a few things, This was made for a single person I used 1 very large potato, 1/2 onion , 1 egg, 2 tbsp of flour, a dash of garlic. Omitted the salt and baking powder, and cooked them in bacon fat. However, I did place the shredded/grated onion and potato, after squeezing out water, in the freezer for about 20/30 minutes. Then added rest of ingredients. They seem to cook up crunchier this way.
These were a little too eggy, I would reduce to one egg. We also added fresh ground pepper, just a pinch. We loved them and I would definitely make them again!
I used Olive oil in my 9" cast iron fry pan. Egg ran all over. Will make again and fry in rings to hold egg from running. Or perhaps in my one-egg pan. Won't use as much salt.
These were good, evem my 5 year old gobbled them up, i used onion powder rather then shredded onion
So good with freshly made applesauce !
The recipe as written produces salty, eggy potato pancakes. Latkes should be crispier than this. As other reviewers mentioned, you should only use one egg, not three.
My first attempt. Even my pickiest eater loved them !
Made as written. Did have to stir in liquid before each scoop into the pan. The kids said it was delicious, and there were no leftovers.
My father was from Lithuania and made these when I was little. This is a fairly close recipe but it needed more onion and some pepper. It's simple and fairly quick to make.

I needed to use some left over potatoes so I made these. I followed others recommendation and used 1 egg per 2 cups and I cut the salt down. These came out great. If I had used the salt called for they would have been too salty for sure.
Mixture a little soupy so added more flour but tasty
My husband and a box grater worked perfectly
You can't go wrong with this recipe , I,made it and it was delicious

This recipe is identical to the one my German Mother-In-Law gave me. The only change that I make is that I place a sieve over a bowl and as I grate the potatoes I place them in the sieve and press them down with a dessert spoon, then I add one spoonful of sour cream. They don't oxidize and the sour cream doesn't affect the flavour.
Really really good. Just as nice as the first ones I made 50years ago! Homemade applesauce and Greek yoghurt instead of sour cream. Perfect!
Yum. A lot of work, but worth it.
I used matzo meal for gluten free latkes and it turned out well. Used sesame oil.
Great simple latke recipe, but I agree with a lot of the other comments - I only used 1 egg per 2 cups of grated potatoes.

I have tried many recipes over three years and have finally found the one here. I didn't grow up eating g latkes since we are not Jewish. The closed thing I had as reference were the tried mashed potato cakes my mom made a couple Joe after having them for dinner. But when I tasted these latkes it was like eating those but with a slightly lighter feel, not so densely packed. But the topping s took them to another level. If my mom had thought to put toppings on here I would have found latkes ages ago. These are just mmm good!

Followed the suggestions and only used one egg- loved it! Only issue is that, like many others, I feel it has too much salt, and I think I doubled the onion, but that's because I love onion. I'll be playing with this a bit to get ready for a holiday party with coworkers, so this might be updated!

3 eggs is way too many--it came out more like potato omelettes than a potato pancakes. I would use only one egg.

That said, my little potato omelettes were delicious.
So yummy
I forgot the egg, didn't stick together! Will make it again for sure
I forgot the egg, didn't stick together! Will make it again for sure
I have made it-it is great. The only thing I did different was put everything in a blender. so much easier. I've been doing it this way for so many years.

The actual latkes had a nice texture, but don't expect to really feel the potato. Consider adding less egg or more potato if you want something with more defined potato shred look. 

Personally, the salt was *way* too much, and my friend ended up shredding in an extra potato and more egg to even the flavor out. Go easy on salt, guys.

Lastly, I like my food extra flavorful so I added more grated onion. Tasted awesome, smelled awesome. If you are cool with onion, you should try this. Go for 2-3 spoons versus just the 1.

5 stars for the concept but as others have noted, I found a few adjustments to the original better suited our tastes.
I did a half recipe using only 1 egg. I add a splash of buttermilk as well. For the taters I used a grater and them let them sit in cold, salted water while I got other stuff ready. I put them in a colander and let them 'drip' dry.

For a few spices beyond the basics, a bit of red pepper flakes, a little seasoning salt and for fun and texture, I ground up a couple of Ritz crackers. Just two as I didn't want them to over-power the texture.
For frying I used coconut oil.
Really nice and tasty and quite quick to make. Had to make a big batch from my oldest son to take to school, although he did a lot of the work as it was his homework!!

Loved these! Even my very picky toddler liked them! Made them pretty much as written but used a shallot instead of onion and fried in vegetable oil. I usually eat my latkes with applesauce but these tasted so good I ate them plain.
Easy instructions.

I love classic latkes, so I made this recipe, but didn’t add any flour. I like my latkes thin and crispy with a chewy center so I make them fairly small, which is why I think I can get away with not using flour. I enjoy them, both, with or without applesauce.

Added a bit more onion, garlic powder and pepper.
Most excellent. Thank you!
I'm sorry, there's too much egg in this. I probably won't make them again, but if I did, would cut the eggs in half. I would also reduce the salt and increase the onion.

I didn't like it because my gramma makes the BEST latkes and i have had many in my jewish life! These latkes can become dry while cooking because you squeeze out all the water out of the potatoes. You need to keep a little bit of water so the potatoes can be hydrated so the latkes can be moist and juicy. Also, DON't EVER SHRED OR GRATE POTATOES. Always dice or cut them into long thin strips for more flavor and better presentation!

Wow so yummy! My Oma used to make these when I was little and now my boys love the ones I made :) I didn't have peanut oil so I used grape seed oil and I didn't have cheese cloth so I used a clean sheet :-p served with cheese and avocado on top and a side of bacon.
I added chopped bacon the family loved it. Will definitely use this recipe again.
Great, almost the way my mom taught me. Be sparing with the oil though and blot them before plating. Only one or two eggs and way less salt. I would only put about 1/2 teaspoon salt.
This dish was awesome and I made no changes. Everyone enjoyed eating and gave the dish a “thumbs up.” I will definitely be making this recipe again and again. Thank you.
Yeeeum!! I shredded and served w tomato salad (on the side;) I had thinly sliced pears, apple sauce and s cream to put on top.
I really liked these - very delicious! My son (age 6) said they were too oily. Otherwise I would have given this recipe 5 stars.
My family loved these!!! I made them gluten free using our gluten free flour and they came out wonderful!!

Wow! This recipe was an amazing hit!! Over the 8 days of Chanukah, I made more than 100 latkes and they were ALL eaten!! Even my fussy husband liked them, a true Chanukah miracle!!
Since I have a daughter that is celiac, I used gluten-free cracker crumbs instead of flour. I followed the other reviewers' suggestions and reduced the eggs and salt, increased the onion and used regular canola oil. 
I would rave some more but I need to go back to the kitchen and make some more yummy latkes!!
No changes needed. Tasted just as good as Grandma's potato latkes
I've made these two years in a row now and everyone loves them. I definitely use less eggs than the recipe calls for.
After mixing all ingredients together, I took a small amount, squeezed out excess liquid/egg, and shaped them before frying. They held together really well and were delicious!
great recipe but i add more onion otherwise they will be a little bland. very similar to my mothers Latkes..

Made this last night. Delicious! Read other reviews and only used 1 egg, 3 T of grated onion. Grated 3 medium potatoes. Used vegetable oil. Must be very hot. Made 8 latkes which fed 4 adults. Just squeezed potatoes between paper towels worked perfect.

Love latkes but these were far too eggy for me. I normally use one egg, preferring the potato flavor to the egg but gave these a shot. Couldn't finish them. For the couple who thought latkes weren't for them, try another recipe.

So I have to say, I followed what many other said. 1 egg, matzo meal....these were like my grandmas!

However, the first batch (for school potato latkes party) I made it with fresh grated potatoes, onions. Yummy!!!

The second time, I cheated and used store bought pre shredded...meh.

FRESH is key! I like mine a bit moist and crunchy outside. Melts In your mouth....??

The pre shredded was too dry and the flavors didn't meld together. Also, too much to chew on. ??

So I have to say, I followed what many other said. 1 egg, matzo meal....these were like my grandmas!

However, the first batch (for school potato latkes party) I made it with fresh grated potatoes, onions. Yummy!!!

The second time, I cheated and used store bought pre shredded...meh.

FRESH is key! I like mine a bit moist and crunchy outside. Melts In your mouth....??

The pre shredded was too dry and the flavors didn't meld together. Also, too much to chew on. ??

Hi there and thanks for the recipe Rachel.

I'm in the UK and I get kind of mixed up with US/metric/imperial measurements but I've worked out how to make a brilliant Yorkshire pudding with equal quantities of egg/flour/milk (plus seasoning) and adapted your latke recipe to this, using onions grated by my trusty Ninja in place of milk. To every 3 egg mixture I add 4 medium/large-ish potatoes, peeled and grated (again in the Ninja.)

I do the batter first (onions grated, then egg, flour, seasoning including a good squirt of garlic paste) and leave it to stand for at least an hour (like Yorkshire pudding) as this allows the flour to expand and blend with the rest of the liquids and prevent it from being stodgy.

Then for the potatoes. Peel and zap them in the machine and tip into a bowl lined with a clean cloth. Draw up edges of cloth and wring them out. You'll get an alarming amount of brownish liquid out ...just keep wringing. Tip liquid away and in the cloth you'll find stuff that looks like cold mashed potatoes. Scrape out into batter mix and mix well. I add more salt at this stage as I love salt (naughty!)

Then I follow your instructions though I just cover the bottom of the pan with oil, corn in my case, flatten gently and fry, turning when bottoms are brown ... ohh delish!

They freeze and heat up well too; did one on a sandwich press today with the sandwich.

If you leave out the onion and garlic they are Irish boxty, very good with butter and jam :)
Too much egg, and it ended up being mushy. Thanks for posting anyway.
These are very good but way too salty next time I'd use half the amount and also half the amount of oil to fry it in

To die for!! These were so easy to make and were absolutely delicious. I used russet potatoes, grated and rinsed them in cold water, then just squeezed the moisture out of them. I used 2 slotted spoons to pick up a big mound and squeezed the egg liquid out before frying in 1/4 inch of corn oil. Crispy and deep golden on the outside and tender on the inside with just the right amount of onion. I did add some coarsely ground black pepper to the mixture, but otherwise made as directed. Served with sour cream or ketchup, they were the perfect side dish instead of the usual mashed or baked potato. I will be making and enjoying these for years to come!

You best change the amount of salt in this recipe! If I had put the 1.5 teaspoons that it called for I would have had to thrown them in the garbage but because I only put 1 teaspoon in and they were just edible (I had read the other reviews and their comments on salt). I only used 1 egg per 2 cups of grated potato (thanks to other reviewers). I also added a dash of baking powder. I also fried them in sunflower oil. Other than the salt issue and eggs, they turned out great!!
Really good. I used a variety of types of potatoes to give it some more colour

I've never had/made latkes before this but found it easy and delicious! I wouldn't recommend green onion on top as there is already plenty of onion in the dish already. I grated my potatoes. Not everyone seems to be doing the potatoes the same way but I found that to be the quickest route outside of buying frozen hash browns.
These came out amazing . Definitely going to make them again . Top it with home made apple sauce ,,,,,, oh my goodness taste like heaven

Great base recipe. Read the reviews and cut back the egg to 1. Added 2 cloves of garlic and fresh dill week. Used Herbamere sea salt/ herb blend instead of salt and added a bit of heat with dried pepper flakes. And a bit of shredded cheese.
I will definitely make these light and delicious latkes again. I added carrots to them which added a beautiful color and more nutritional value.

I followed some of the other reviews and decided to only use one egg instead of 3; they came out perfect, and tasted wonderful! Also, since I didn't have any cheesecloth on hand, I simply put half of the shredded potatoes in a clean dish towel and squeezed the moisture out, and then repeated with the other half; it worked just fine.

These were great! I used the food processor to shred the potatoes so this recipe was super simple too. The sign of a truly great recipe...? I made these two nights ago and now the family has requested them again for Sunday breakfast. I too doubled the onion and the flavor was spot on for us. Thanks for a great, easy recipe :)

Potato Latkes I Haiku: "Too egg-y for me. I grated my potatoes, instead of shredding." I let my grated potato drain for awhile to ensure maximum dryness, but found that the eggs called for in this recipe overtook the potato taste that I want to shine when I make this ultra-healthy dish. I mean, once a year I make latkes, maybe twice if I'm feeling sassy, b/c I feel so guilty when I devour them w/ sour cream and applesauce, but this recipe didn't do it enough for us for me to make them again anytime soon.
I felt that the recipe was too "wet" and eggy to produce crisp pancakes!

I've used this recipe and it's good! But here's a new idea for anyone who juices. I used the pulp left from juicing carrots to make delicious carrot latkes! Simply sub them for the strained shredded potatoes.
Half the salt is best.

Great for a cold snow day,had some cooked potatoes in the fridge so peeled and grated them added only 2 eggs and no flour , used scallions because it was what was on hand---cooked them in a modest amount of butter on a medium flame -- very satisfying and will be made again.
It was good.

I grew up eating these potato pancakes and loved them served with applesauce. But every time I attempted to make them, I failed miserably and thought I would never get to enjoy them again......that is until I came across this recipe. FINALLY, I got my wish! I made these for dinner last night along with Pork Tenderloin and I cannot say enough how much my husband (married 33 years and HE never got his wish for these either) and I loved these. I followed the recipe exactly and they came out nice and crispy brown on the outside and tender on the inside. I couldn't believe how easy it was to make these potatoes! Now we can have them any time we want to and I'm sure we'll be making up for lost time!! Thank you, Rachel for a GREAT recipe!!

I've never made latkes before, so I wasn't sure exactly what I was looking for. However, I'm glad I followed the advice of only using 1 egg as opposed to 3. I definitely feel like three would have made them way too eggy. One was just enough to bind two cups of potatoes together. I also used sunflower oil instead of peanut oil with no problems. Tasted like a glorified hashbrown! I would make these again.

The Rating does not necessarily reflect the recipe. I think since i must be gluten free, and i used gluten free flower, that made the cakes have a strange taste. I was ok with it more than my family. It was a total bust for us. 
I used Bobs Red Mill flour and from what i hear, that is not the best tasting flower but the only one i can find in the stores in my area so far.
If anyone else out there has celiac disease, use a flower that is not Bobs Red Mill and you may have better results.
BTW, it smelt wonderful cooking. Really sorry this didn't work but i will try again with a decent GF Flour and re-rate.

I made as directed and they came out really wet. I did ring out the potatoes, they were bone dry but there was a lot of egg mixture left over. Next time I will definitely triple the onion and halve the eggs and salt. and add pepper. good basis recipe though

Wonderful...by the time dinner was ready I had already eaten most of the Potato Latkes. I tried a little sample when they were done and could not stop eating them. Especially nice dipped in sour cream. These are crispy on the outside and soft on the inside,or you can say they are light and flaky..just perfect, these are the best ever. 
 They were gone before dinner.. The few I had left disappeared between the kitchen and the dinning room table..The 2 people helping me put 'dinner on the table' also gave them a 5 star, best ever rating. You will love these!!
note: After the potatoes are shredded I did put them in a flour sack dish towel (I didn't have cheese cloth) and squeezed the liquid out before adding the rest of the ingredients. This is an important step, and boy what a difference it makes. You will love these!!!
Joanne
Good basic recipe. I will only add one egg next time - found them a bit eggy. I also substituted onion powder for the grated onion due to picky children.

My son just loved these (although how could you not love fried potato). After reading the reviews, I only used 1 egg, which was plenty. I also reduced the salt to 3/4 tsp, though I think I would use a full tsp next time. I'd also bump up the onion a little - maybe another tablespoon.
The entire family loved these! I didn't have peanut oil. Vegetable oil worked great. Used frozen hashbrowns from a bag too. Just defrost them first.
